item.title: Frango Da Guia (Peri Peri Chicken)
item.description: For the Peri Peri sauce (optional) 1-4 peri peri chilies, or as many as you have (adjust the amount based on desired spiciness) 1 teaspoon brown sugar 3 garlic cloves 2 teaspoons sweet/spicy paprika Extra virgin olive oil A bit of fresh ginger Ground black pepper Salt Dried oregano 1 teaspoon soy sauce 40 ml white vinegar (or wine) 2 teaspoons lemon juice Instructions Prepare the chicken: Clean the chicken and cut it into pieces (thighs, breasts, wings, etc.

item.title: Garlic bread
item.description: Prepare the garlic butter: In a small bowl, mix the softened butter with minced garlic, chopped parsley, and a pinch of salt. If desired, add some grated Parmesan for extra flavor. Slice the bread: Cut the baguette or loaf into slices, making sure not to cut all the way through so the slices stay connected at the bottom. Spread the garlic butter: Using a knife or spoon, spread the garlic butter mixture between each slice and across the top of the bread.

item.title: Pilpil prawns
item.description: Peel the prawns or shrimp and set them aside. Heat the oil over medium heat. Peel the garlic cloves and slice them thinly. Lower the heat and add the garlic and cayenne peppers, frying until the garlic is golden brown. Remove the pan from the heat and add a teaspoon of paprika, stirring to prevent it from burning. Add the prawns and let them cook in the residual heat. If using shrimp, cook for an additional minute or two over the heat until they change color.

item.title: Piquillo peppers
item.description: Prepare the Garlic and Parsley: Finely mince the garlic and chop the parsley. Assemble the Peppers: Place the drained piquillo peppers on a serving plate. Season: Sprinkle the minced garlic and chopped parsley evenly over the peppers. Dress with Olive Oil: Drizzle the olive oil generously over the peppers, making sure each pepper is coated. Add salt to taste. Marinate and Serve: Let the peppers sit for about 10-15 minutes to allow the flavors to blend.

item.title: Quail with majao
item.description: Make the majao (garlic paste): In a mortar, crush the garlic with a pinch of salt until you form a smooth paste. Optionally add the paprika and mix well. Prepare the quails: Clean the quails and season them with salt and pepper. If you prefer, you can marinate them with the majao for an hour or two to enhance the flavor. Cook the quails: Heat a good amount of olive oil in a large frying pan over medium heat.

item.title: Stuffed mushrooms with garlic and parsley
item.description: Remove the stems and thoroughly wash the mushrooms to eliminate any dirt or sand. It’s important not to remove the skin in this case, as they could burn (especially if cooked in a pan). Take a handful of parsley and as many garlic cloves as you think necessary, depending on how many mushrooms you want to prepare. Finely chop the garlic and parsley, and let them marinate with a good drizzle of olive oil.
